Subjects: God, appeal of, to man; dialogues, God and man
_description: The Complaint of God — eleven 12-line stanzas (ababababbcbc) with refrain, ‘Whi art þou to þi frend vnkinde’

Bod596.First Lines:
This is goddes owene compleyntffro man to man þat he hath
                    bogh…
Bod596.Last Lines:
…Or wepyng we mowe sey allasWhy were we to oure lord
                    vnkynde

BodRawC86.First Lines:
Thys is goddis avne compleynteffro man to man þat he hath
                    wrouȝt…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…Or Wepynge w shall seye alasThat euer we were to oure frende
                    vnkynde

BLAdd39574.First Lines:
THis is goddis owne compleyntffro man to man þat he haþ
                    wrouȝt…
BLAdd39574.Last Lines:
…Or wepynge we mown seye allasWhy were we to oure freend
                    vnkynde
BLAdd39574.Editions:
Day,  Mabel,
                        ed.  
             The Wheatley Manuscript: Middle English Verse and Prose in British
                Museum MS. Additional 39574.
EETS
         o.s. 155 (1921; repr. 1971): 69-73.

BLHar2380.First Lines:
[Þ]is gods awn complaynt fro man to man þat he as
                    w…Þus he says vs to Ateynt Myn haun pepyll qwat
                    haf…
BLHar2380.Last Lines:
…Or we moun syng and say a laysÞat we haf ben so lange
                    vnkynd
BLHar2380.Note:
Space left for ornamental inital Þ, which was left blank. Two verse
                    lines per manuscript line. Some manuscript damage to line endings. Folio number
                    reflects the most recent foliation.

NLS3473.First Lines:
This is goddis awne complaintfro man to man that he has
                    boucht…
NLS3473.Last Lines:
…or wepand we mone say allaceþat we bene til our freind
                    vnkynd
NLS3473.Note:
Another three stanzas on ff. 77-77v added by a later hand,
                    the missing stanzas from this copy: beginning, ‘Man I haue bocht thi luf
                    full deir’; Edinburgh,  Edinburgh University Library La.III.450/1 [olim Laing 450], ff. 83-83v,
                        84v-85, 84-84v is nineteenth-century transcript by
                    Laing.

Lam306.First Lines:
This is the comepleynt off godffro man to man that he haþe
                    bouȝte…
Lam306.Last Lines:
…that we mowe with weepyng crye alasfor that wee were to oure
                    frende onkyndeExplicit
Lam306.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other

EETS

Lam853.First Lines:
THis is goddis owne complayntTo euery man þat he haþ
                    bouȝtAnd þus he seiþ to hem atayntMyne owne peple what
                    han ȝe wrouȝt…
Lam853.Last Lines:
…A blissid lady fair of faceHelp for we be fer
                    bihyndeÞat we wiþ wepynge moun crie alasffor þat we
                    were to oure freend vnkind AMEN

Scottish Text Society

HarEng530.First Lines:
In Almys dar thow do no thyngfor drede thow falle in to
                    pouertIn wordys [and] in veyne spekyngWhat euer thow wastyst thow mery
                    art…
HarEng530.Last Lines:
…Now Ihesu lord þou well vs wysseWyth angelys world with
                    owte endeThat to Thy choson ordeynyd ysseThat leevyn synne and hem
                    amende
